sentences.sentence: The youth continued his journey, and once more began to say to himself, “Ah, if I could be scared( 被惊吓 )!”
A wagon( 马车 ) driver who was passing heard him and asked, “Who are you?”
“I don’t know yet,” answered the youth.
Then the driver asked, “Where do you come from?”
“I couldn’t say.”
“Who is your father?”
“I’m not allowed to tell you.”
“What were you just saying to yourself?”
“Ah,” replied the youth, “I want to be scared, but no one will teach me how.”
“Come with me,” said the driver, “and I will see if I can help you.”
The youth went with the driver, and in the evening they arrived at an inn( 小旅馆 ) where they wished to pass the night.
Then at the entrance of the room the youth again said quite loudly, “If only I could be scared!”
The host( 主人 ) who heard this, laughed and said, “If that is what you want, perhaps we can help you.”
“Be silent,” said his wife.
“So many brave people have already lost their lives.
It would be a shame if such beautiful eyes as this young man’s should never see the daylight again.”
But the youth said, “However difficult it may be, I will learn to be scared—that when I have gone out into the world to do.”
He let the host have no rest, until finally the host told him that not far from there was a haunted( 闹鬼的 ) castle( 城堡 ).
Anyone could very easily be scared, if he would only spend three nights there and stay awake the whole time.
The King had promised that whoever could succeed in doing that could marry his daughter, who was the most beautiful girl under the sun.
And there were many treasures in the castle, guarded by evil( 邪恶的 ) spirits.
Anyone who could overcome( 战胜 ) the spirits would win the treasures, and be rich enough to do anything he wanted.
Already many men had gone into the castle, but so far none had come out again.
The next morning the youth went to the King, and said that he would like to spend three nights in the haunted castle.
The King looked at him, and as the youth pleased him, he said,
“You may ask for three things to take into the castle with you, but they must be things without life.”
Then he answered, “Then I ask for a fire, a turning lathe( 旋床 ), and a cutting board with a knife.”
The King had these things taken into the castle for him during the day.
When it started to get dark, the boy went into the castle and made himself a bright fire in one of the rooms.
He placed the cutting board and knife beside it, and seated himself by the turning lathe.
“Ah, if I could only be scared!” said he.
“But I don’t expect I shall learn it here either.”
Toward midnight he was about to( 打算 ) poke( 拨火 ) his fire, and as he was blowing it, something cried suddenly from one corner,
“Miaow( 喵 ) Miaow! How cold we are!”
“Don’t be stupid!” cried he.
“What are you crying about? If you are cold, come and sit by the fire and warm yourselves.”
And when he had said that, two great black cats came with one tremendous( 极快的 ) leap( 跳跃 ) and sat down on each side of him, and looked savagely( 恶狠狠地 ) at him with their fiery( 火红的 ) eyes.
After a short time, when they had warmed themselves, they said, “Friend, shall we have a game of cards?”
“Why not?” he replied, “But just show me your paws( 爪子 ).”
Then they stretched( 伸出 ) out their claws( 脚爪 ).
“Oh,” said he, “what long nails( 趾甲 ) you have!
Wait, I must first cut them for you.”
So he grabbed( 抓住 ) the enormous( 庞大的 ) cats, placed their paws on the cutting board, cut off their long claws with the knife, and then threw them out of the castle( 城堡 ) into the river.
But when he had finished with these two, and was about to sit down again by his fire,
out from every hole and corner came gigantic( 巨大的 ) black cats and black dogs with red-hot chains( 链条 ) around their necks,
and more and more of them came until he had no room to move.
They howled( 嚎叫 ) horribly( 可怕地 ), jumped into the fire, pulled it to pieces, and tried to put it out.
He watched them for a while quietly, but finally he picked up his knife, and cried, “Go away, you terrible creatures( 怪物 )!” and attacked them.
He killed some and threw their bodies into the river, and the rest ran away.
When all the cats and dogs were gone, he got the fire going again and warmed himself.
And as he sat there, he started to feel very sleepy.
Then he looked round and saw a great bed in the corner.
“That is just what I need,” he said, and got into it.
When he was just going to shut his eyes, however, the bed began to move on its own, and went around the whole of the castle.
“That’s good,” he said, “but go faster!”
Then the bed traveled on as if six horses were pulling it, up and down, through doors and over steps.
Then suddenly it turned upside down and lay on top of him, and seemed as heavy as a mountain.
But he crawled( 爬行 ) out from underneath, taking some blankets( 毛毯 ) and pillows( 枕头 ) with him, and said, “Now it’s someone else’s turn to drive.”
Then he lay down by the fire, and slept till it was day.

question.cn: 国王承诺那些可以在城堡中幸存的人什么？
question.en: What did the King promise to those who could survive in the castle?

analysis: 文中提到：“The King had promised that whoever could succeed in doing that could marry his daughter, who was the most beautiful girl under the sun. And there were many treasures in the castle, guarded by evil spirits. Anyone who could overcome the spirits would win the treasures, and be rich enough to do anything he wanted.”因此答案选A。

question.cn: 什么东西不能被带到城堡？
question.en: What could not be taken into the castle？

analysis: 文中提到：“'You may ask for three things to take into the castle with you, but they must be things without life.’”有生命的东西是不能被带到城堡的，因此答案选C。

question.en: What happened to the cats and dogs in the end?

options.cn: 一些被杀掉，一些逃走了。
options.en: Some were killed and some ran away.

analysis: 文中提到：“He killed some and threw their bodies into the river, and the rest ran away.”因此答案选C。
